terms.definition: A fully convolutional encoder-decoder architecture with skip connections between corresponding encoder and decoder layers, originally designed for biomedical image segmentation.
Ultra Accelerator Link industry standard for high-speed chip-to-chip interconnection between AI accelerators. Being developed as an open alternative to proprietary interconnects like NVLink.
A dataset of 13320 video clips from 101 action categories collected from YouTube. One of the most widely used benchmarks for human action recognition in video.
A dataset from the 1994 Census database predicting whether income exceeds 50000 dollars per year. One of the most commonly used tabular classification benchmarks.
A collection of databases domain theories and data generators used by the machine learning community since 1987. One of the oldest and most cited dataset repositories.
Universal Chiplet Interconnect Express open standard for die-to-die interconnection. Enables chiplets from different manufacturers to communicate within a single package for modular AI chip design.

Upper Confidence bounds applied to Trees combines Monte Carlo tree search with the UCB1 bandit formula for node selection. Balances exploration of less-visited nodes with exploitation of promising branches.
A GAN-boosted diffusion model that achieves one-step text-to-image generation while maintaining the diversity and quality of multi-step diffusion models.
Industry consortium developing next-generation Ethernet standards optimized for AI and HPC workloads. Aims to make Ethernet competitive with InfiniBand for large-scale AI training clusters.
A large-scale multi-round dialogue dataset containing 1.5 million conversations covering diverse topics. Generated through carefully designed prompting strategies for instruction tuning.
A large-scale instruction-based image editing model trained on automatically generated editing pairs for following complex text-guided image modification commands.
A large-scale preference dataset containing 64000 prompts with multiple model responses rated by GPT-4. Used for training reward models and direct preference optimization.

Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection, a nonlinear dimensionality reduction method that constructs a topological representation of high-dimensional data and optimizes a low-dimensional embedding to preserve its structure. It is faster than t-SNE and better preserves global structure.

Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection constructs a high-dimensional graph and optimizes a low-dimensional layout to preserve topological structure. Faster than t-SNE and better at preserving global data structure.

A concept introduced by roboticist Masahiro Mori in 1970 describing the dip in human comfort when encountering robots or animations that closely but imperfectly resemble humans. The uncanny valley has implications for the design of humanoid robots and virtual characters.
When a model is too simple to capture patterns in the data, performing poorly on both training and test data. Addressed by increasing model capacity or training longer.
A strategy for addressing class imbalance by randomly removing examples from the majority class to create a more balanced training set, potentially at the cost of losing useful information.
The first global standard on AI ethics, adopted by UNESCO member states in 2021, providing a comprehensive framework covering values, principles, and policy areas for ethical AI governance.

The U-Net backbone commonly used in diffusion models as the denoising network, incorporating timestep conditioning, cross-attention for text conditioning, and skip connections for multi-scale feature preservation.
Unified Autonomous Driving is an end-to-end framework that jointly handles perception and prediction and planning in a single network for self-driving vehicles.
A universal monocular metric depth estimation model that predicts depth and camera intrinsics simultaneously for any image without camera information.

A fundamental algorithm in logic and computer science that finds a substitution making two terms identical. Essential to Prolog and automated theorem proving unification was formalized by John Alan Robinson in 1965 as part of his resolution principle.
NVIDIA CUDA feature providing a single address space accessible from both CPU and GPU with automatic data migration. Simplifies programming for applications that process data on both processors.

A model that unifies diverse vision and language tasks in a single architecture using a sequence-to-sequence framework. Handles image generation segmentation visual question answering and region captioning with shared parameters.
A graph search algorithm that expands the node with the lowest cumulative path cost. Equivalent to Dijkstra's algorithm and guarantees finding the optimal path in graphs with non-negative edge costs.

A probability distribution where all outcomes in a given range are equally likely. The continuous version has constant density over an interval, while the discrete version assigns equal probability to each value.

A theoretical framework underlying UMAP that models data as lying on a Riemannian manifold. Uses fuzzy simplicial sets to represent the topological structure and finds low-dimensional representations preserving that structure.

A subword tokenization method that starts with a large vocabulary and iteratively removes tokens that least affect the overall likelihood. Unlike BPE which builds up vocabulary this approach prunes down. Used in SentencePiece.
A subword tokenization method that starts with a large vocabulary and iteratively removes tokens whose loss has the least impact on the overall corpus likelihood, using a unigram language model.
A subword tokenization algorithm that starts with a large vocabulary and iteratively removes tokens to minimize the overall loss on the training corpus, finding an optimal compact vocabulary.
A unified model for dense matching tasks including optical flow and stereo matching and depth estimation using a shared Transformer architecture.

The first industrial robot installed on a General Motors assembly line in 1961. Developed by George Devol and Joseph Engelberger Unimate performed tasks like die casting and spot welding marking the beginning of industrial robotics.

A prior distribution that expresses minimal information about the parameter before observing data, such as a uniform distribution over the parameter space, allowing the data to dominate the posterior.

Outcomes of AI deployment that were not anticipated or intended by developers. Arise from complex interactions between AI systems and social environments and highlight the limits of prediction in sociotechnical systems.
Battery backup system that provides emergency power to computing equipment during outages. Critical for AI data centers to prevent loss of training progress during power interruptions.
A Universal Simulator that generates realistic experience through generative simulation for training embodied agents in diverse interactive environments.
A self-supervised speech representation model from Microsoft that uses contrastive learning with phonetic labels for improved speech recognition and understanding.
First commercial computer in the United States delivered to the US Census Bureau in 1951. Built by Eckert and Mauchly it famously predicted the 1952 presidential election.

A theorem proving that feedforward neural networks with a single hidden layer containing a finite number of neurons can approximate any continuous function on compact subsets of R^n. First proved by George Cybenko in 1989 for sigmoid networks.
Proposals for unconditional periodic cash payments to all citizens, discussed as a potential policy response to widespread job displacement caused by AI and automation technologies.
A cross-linguistically consistent framework for annotating grammar including parts of speech, morphological features, and syntactic dependencies, enabling multilingual NLP model development.

A model that encodes text into high-dimensional vectors for transfer learning across NLP tasks. Available in transformer and deep averaging network variants. Produces fixed-size sentence embeddings useful for semantic similarity.

A Turing machine that can simulate any other Turing machine given a description of that machine on its tape. Proposed by Alan Turing in 1936 the concept anticipated stored-program computers and established that a single machine could be programmed for any computable task.

A nonlinear state estimation method that uses carefully chosen sigma points to capture the mean and covariance of the state distribution. More accurate than the extended Kalman filter for highly nonlinear systems.

A pruning approach that removes individual weights regardless of their position in the weight matrix, resulting in sparse matrices. Unstructured pruning achieves higher compression ratios but requires sparse matrix hardware or software support for speedup.

A framework where a teacher agent or mechanism automatically generates training environments at the frontier of the student agent's capabilities. Methods like PAIRED and PLR create adaptive curricula that maximize learning progress.
Machine learning from unlabeled data, discovering patterns without explicit guidance. Includes clustering, dimensionality reduction, and self-supervised pre-training of LLMs.
AI hardware company developing at-memory compute architectures that place processing elements directly at SRAM banks to minimize data movement and maximize energy efficiency.

A family of bandit algorithms that select the action with the highest upper confidence bound on its expected reward, combining the estimated reward with an exploration bonus that decreases as the action is sampled more.
Increasing resolution or quantity of data. In image AI, upscaling low-res images. In training, duplicating underrepresented examples to balance datasets.
A dataset of 8732 labeled sound excerpts of urban sounds in 10 categories including sirens drilling and street music. Used for urban environment audio classification research.
A specific application or scenario where AI provides value. Understanding your use case helps choose the right model, prompting strategy, and safety measures.
The input provided by the user in a conversation, as opposed to the system prompt set by developers. Together with system prompts, they form the complete context for AI responses.
Universal Speech Model is a 2 billion parameter model from Google trained on 12 million hours of speech for automatic speech recognition across 300+ languages.
A mathematical function that measures how "good" an outcome is. In AI alignment, designing utility functions that capture human values is a fundamental challenge.

An iterative method for solving saddle-point problems arising from constrained optimization. Alternates between solving a system for the primal variable and updating the dual variable with a gradient ascent step.
